raw_text:
Britain boosted by Holmes double
 
 Athletics fans endured a year of mixed emotions in 2004 as stunning victories went hand-in-hand with disappointing defeats and more drugs scandals.
 
 Kelly Holmes finally fulfilled her potential by storming to double gold on the track at the Olympic Games. Holmes helped erase the gloom hanging over Team GB after their biggest medal hope, Paula Radcliffe, dropped out of the marathon and then the 10,000m. Britain's men's 4x100m relay team also did their bit by taking a shock gold. Holmes had started the year in disappointing style, falling over in the final of 1500m at the World Indoor Championships where she was favourite. Her Olympic build-up was clouded by self doubt but that proved unfounded as she overhauled rival Maria Mutola to win the 800m - her first global title. Just five days later, the 34-year-old made it double gold in the 1500m. It was the first time in 84 years a Briton has achieved the Olympic middle-distance double. While Holmes left Athens as the star of Team GB, it was Radcliffe who carried expectations before the August Games.
 
 The 30-year-old marathon world record holder went into the Athens event as favourite but an exhausted Radcliffe dropped out after 23 miles in tears. Her decision to enter the 10,000m five days later also backfired as she again pulled out with eight laps remaining.
 
 But Radcliffe helped put her Olympic trauma behind her with a thrilling win in November's New York Marathon. The 4x100m team grabbed some last-gasp glory for the British men's Olympic squad after a poor start to the Games.
 
 It seemed as though Athens would be the first Games where the men would fail to win a medal with Michael East the only individual track finalist in the 1500m. But Darren Campell, Jason Gardener, Marlon Devonish and Mark Lewis-Francis made amends in the sprint relay. The quartet held off favourites the USA to win Britain's first relay medal since 1912 in 38.07 seconds. Gardener added the Olympic relay crown to his World Indoor title over 60m and, just like Holmes, finally lived up to his promise in 2004. Kelly Sotherton completed Team GB's athletics medal haul in Athens with a surprise bronze in the heptathlon. The 28-year-old won her first championship medal since becoming a full-time athlete in 2003.
 
 But it was a different story for Britain's defending champion Denise Lewis, who withdrew on day two of the competition after some poor results. Lewis, who was troubled by injury, has ruled out retiring while Sotherton is tipped to build on her success. The Athens Olympics proved to be a landmark occasion for Steve Backley, who retired from competition after finishing fourth in the javelin. The battling 35-year-old leaves the sport with a vast medal haul including two silvers and one Olympic bronze.
 
 And Backley's departure was balanced by the return of injury-hit decathlete Dean Macey, who came fourth in Athens.
 
 The continued improvement of sprinter Abi Oyepitan and long jumper Chris Tomlinson also boosted Team GB. Sadly, the 2004 Olympics did not escape the problems of drugs misuse. On the eve of the Games, Greek sprinters Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou missed a drugs test and claimed to have been involved in a road crash.
 
 Kenteris, the 200m champion in 2000, and Thanou have since been charged by the Greek authorities and await trial. At the Games, Adrian Annus (hammer), Robert Fazelas (discus) and Irina Korzhanenko (shot) were all stripped of their titles because of doping issues. Hungarian compatriots Annus and Fazelas both refused to give urine samples while Russian Korzhanenko tested positive for the steroid stanozolol.
 
 The fallout from the THG scandal, which rocked the sport in 2003, continued to impact in Olympic year. Britain's 4x100m team took gold without the services of Dwain Chambers, who was handed a two-year ban in February after testing positive for steroid THG.
 
 American Kelli White was suspended and stripped of her world 100m and 200m titles after failing a drugs test. And world 400m champion Jerome Young landed a life ban from US chiefs after a second doping offence. Russian pole vaulter Yelena Isinbayeva provided some light relief by smashing the world record seven times on her way to the World Indoor and Olympic titles. Her rivalry with compatriot Svetlana Feofanova livened up the field events. Morocco's Hicham El Guerrouj also delighted fans by racing to a historic Olympic double in the 1500m and 5,000m.
 
 And though there was no Paula Radcliffe in the London Marathon, there was plenty of drama as Kenyans Evans Rutto and Margaret Okayo took the titles. Rutto held on to win despite slipping on some cobblestones and tumbling into a barrier. Okayo also had to battle back after mistiming her tactics but clinched victory on her debut.
llama3.2:1b:
Britain's athletics teams secured a range of medals at the 2004 Athens Olympics, including double gold for Kelly Holmes in the 800m and 1500m events, as well as bronze for Kelly Sotherton in the heptathlon.

The country's men's relay team also achieved their first medal since 1912, with Darren Campell, Jason Gardener, Marlon Devonish, and Mark Lewis-Francis winning gold.

Britain's women's teams performed inconsistently throughout the Games, but standout performances included Kelly Sotherton's bronze in the heptathlon, Denise Lewis' withdrawal from competition due to injury, and Abi Oyepitan's improvement.

The country also saw significant doping issues, with several athletes being stripped of their titles for testing positive.
llama3.2:3b: Kelly Holmes won double gold in 800m and 1500m at the Olympics, erasing gloom over Team GB. Paula Radcliffe dropped out of the marathon before Athens due to exhaustion, but came back strong with a win in November's New York Marathon. Britain's men's 4x100m relay team took surprise gold, and Jason Gardener won Olympic relay crown. Denise Lewis withdrew from competition due to injury, while Steve Backley retired after finishing fourth in javelin. The Olympics were marred by doping scandals affecting athletes from Greece, Hungary, Russia, and the US, including Dwain Chambers' two-year ban for steroid use.
gemma2:2b: Kelly Holmes won double gold in the 800m and 1500m at the Olympic Games, becoming the first Briton to achieve this feat since 1924. Paula Radcliffe's unexpected withdrawals from the marathon and 10,000m affected Team GB, but she later triumphed in the New York Marathon. The men's 4x100m relay team secured gold after an impressive last-gasp performance.  Team GB athletes also achieved success in the heptathlon, javelin throw, sprint events, and long jump. Despite individual medalists' successes, doping scandals at the Games disrupted the athletic landscape, as several athletes were stripped of their medals due to violations.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
The article discusses British athletics' achievements in the 2004 Olympics, focusing on Kelly Holmes and the men's relay team. 

Key points:
- Kelly Holmes achieved her first Olympic double by winning both the 1500m and 800m races.
- The women's 4x100m relay team also won gold in Athens, led by Michael East.
- British athletes had a mixed year with performances in various events: 
  - Paula Radcliffe dropped out of the marathon due to injuries. Britain won for the first time ever after her second-place finish.
  - The 34-year-old Maria Mutola overcame a poor start and went on to win her second medal of the Games.
  - Mark Lewis-Francis in the sprint relay team achieved their first Olympic medal since 1968.

The article notes that British athletes, particularly Kelly Holmes, were facing challenges due to drugs scandals, but their performances were largely successful. The Olympics provided a significant moment for British athletics by showcasing medals for women and bringing back medals lost due to doping issues from previous years.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Britain won two gold medals in Athens 2004, with Kelly Holmes achieving the Olympic middle-distance double as Paula Radcliffe was eliminated from both marathons she contested before recovering to win New York Marathon. Athletics included a mixed performance with some doping issues affecting competitors like Kostas Kenteris and Adrian Annus.
qwen2.5:3b: Britain's athletics team experienced mixed emotions in 2004, with standout performances alongside disappointing results, drugs scandals, and setbacks. Kelly Holmes achieved double gold at the Olympics, overcoming personal doubts. Paula Radcliffe failed to finish both marathons she entered, causing further gloom for Team GB. The men's 4x100m relay team won a shock gold medal. Steve Backley retired after finishing fourth in the javelin, while Dean Macey returned from injury. Abi Oyeitan and Chris Tomlinson showed improvement. Drugs issues continued to affect the sport; several athletes were sanctioned for doping violations, including Kostas Kiosis and Katerina Thanou of Greece who faced legal action over their absences from a drugs test. Notably, Moroccan Hicham El Guerrouj won two Olympic events (1500m and 5000m) in Athens, adding to the medal count with Yelena Isinbayeva smashing world records.

Britain boosted by Holmes double
 Athletics fans endured a year of mixed emotions in 2004 as stunning victories went hand-in-hand with disappointing defeats and more drugs scandals.
 
 Kelly Holmes finally fulfilled her potential by storming to double gold on the track at the Olympic Games. Holmes helped erase the gloom hanging over Team GB after their biggest medal hope, Paula Radcliffe, dropped out of the marathon. Her decision to enter the 10,000m five days later also backfired as she again fell short.
 
 But Holmes had already lived up to her Olympic promise in 2003 when she won gold at the World Indoor Championships and was named British Athlete of the Year.
 
 The 34-year-old marathon world record holder went into the Athens Games with a healthy dose of optimism, but it seemed as though she would have to settle for second place after the first day's results showed her finishing behind the likes of Usain Bolt and Carl Lewis.
 
 But Radcliffe helped put her back in the game by winning the 10,000m on the last day of competition. Her victory was a welcome relief from the disappointing finish to the bronze medal she had won at the 2003 World Indoor Championships.
 
 The 40-year-old sprinter's return to form in Athens helped boost Team GB's overall medal tally, but it seemed as though her biggest achievement came too late for the Games.
 
 British sprinter Kelli White was suspended and stripped of her world 100m and 200m titles after failing a drugs test. And American Kelli White provided some light relief by smashing the world record seven times on her way to the World Indoor and Olympic titles. Her rivalry with compatriot Svetlana Feofanova also delighted fans as she raced to a historic Olympic double in the 1500m and 5,000m.
 
 And though there was no Paula Radcliffe in the London Marathon, there was plenty of drama as Kenyans Evans Rutto and Margaret Okayo took the titles. Rutto helped erase the gloom hanging over Team GB after their biggest medal hope, Paula Radcliffe, dropped out of the marathon. Her decision to enter the 10,000m five days later also backfired as she again fell short.
 
 But Evans Rutto and Okayo had already lived up to her Olympic promise in 2003 when they won gold at the World Indoor Championships and were named British Athlete of the Year.

 But Okayo helped put her back in the game by winning the 10,000m on the last day of competition. Her victory was a welcome relief from the disappointing finish to the bronze medal she had won at the 2003 World Indoor Championships.

The British team achieved double gold for Michael East in the 1500m, a record set since 1912, marking a milestone. However, Paula Radcliffe, whose performance was overshadowed by drug misuse, faced defeat after dropping out of the marathon and the 10,000m relay.

Despite Radcliffe's challenges, she overcame her issues and secured another thrilling win in the 10,000m at the 1500m event. Her Olympic trauma was amicably backfired when she won the 800m with a strong performance, setting a new record.

The British team's success led to significant improvement for others: Kelly Holmes earned double gold in the 4x100m relay, and Darren Campell brought his world indoor records into view. American stars Jason Gardener and Mark Lewis-Francis also added to their奥运 performance with strong finishes.

Despite the mixed emotions, Britain's sprinter Abi Oyepitan and long jumper Chris Tomlinson made a remarkable comeback, solidifying their Olympic presence. The global drama included Kenyans Evans Rutto and Margaret Okayo claiming titles despite challenges. The event also saw significant improvement in team performance, with Radcliffe's return adding a much-needed lift.

Overall, 2004 showcased the resilience of Britain's athletes as they navigated the complex world of sports, including drug issues and personal struggles.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
In 2004, Britain's athletic performance fluctuated amid disappointments and scandals. Key figures included Kelly Holmes, who achieved double gold in the 800m and 1500m, becoming the first Briton to win Olympic middle-distance doubles in 84 years. Paula Radcliffe, the marathon world record holder, had expectations but dropped out after 23 miles in both the marathon and 10,000m races. Despite these setbacks, she won the New York Marathon to redeem herself. The British men's 4x100m relay team surprised with a gold medal win after a poor start.

Kelly Sotherton secured bronze in the heptathlon, while Denise Lewis withdrew due to injury on day two. Steve Backley retired from competition following his fourth-place finish in the javelin and left with a significant medal collection. Dean Macey made a return after an injury-plagued career, ranking fourth in the decathlon. Abi Oyepitan and Chris Tomlinson improved for Team GB.

The Games were marred by drug scandals, including Greek sprinters Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou's doping charges and subsequent disqualifications. Hungarian hammer thrower Adam Niedzielski and discus thrower Robert Fazelas, as well as Russian shot putter Irina Korzhanenko, were stripped of their titles due to doping violations. Britain's 4x100m team competed without Dwain Chambers, who received a two-year ban for positive THG test results. American sprinter Kelli White was suspended and lost her world titles after testing positive. Jerome Young received a life ban from US authorities for a second doping offense.

Russian pole vaulter Yelena Isinbayeva shone with seven world record performances, enhancing the field events, while Moroccan Hicham El Guerrouj won historic Olympic doubles in the 1500m and 5,000m. In the marathon, Kenyans Evans Rutto and Margaret Okayo claimed the titles after a dramatic finish involving cobblestones and barriers for Rutto and Okayo's tactical mishaps.
